Route a controller to a URI with wildcard routing.

comment.value: First, we will check to see if a controller prefix has been registered in
the route group. If it has, we will need to prefix it before trying to
reflect into the class instance and pull out the method for routing.
When a controller is routed using this method, we use Reflection to parse
out all of the routable methods for the controller, then register each
route explicitly for the developers, so reverse routing is possible.

description.compact: Register an inspected controller route.

comment.value: If a given controller method has been named, we will assign the name to the
controller action array, which provides for a short-cut to method naming
so you don't have to define an individual route for these controllers.

description.compact: Add a fallthrough route for a controller.
Register an array of resource controllers.
Route a resource to a controller.
Create a route group with shared attributes.

comment.value: Once we have updated the group stack, we will execute the user Closure and
merge in the groups attributes when the route is created. After we have
run the callback, we will pop the attributes off of this group stack.

description.compact: Update the group stack with the given attributes.
Merge the given array with the last group stack.
Merge the given group attributes.
Format the uses prefix for the new group attributes.
Format the prefix for the new group attributes.
Get the prefix from the last group on the stack.
Add a route to the underlying route collection.
Create a new route instance.

comment.value: If the route is routing to a controller we will parse the route action into
an acceptable array format before registering it and creating this route
instance itself. We need to build the Closure that will call this out.
If we have groups that need to be merged, we will merge them now after this
route has already been created and is ready to go. After we're done with
the merge we will be ready to return the route back out to the caller.

description.compact: Create a new Route object.
Prefix the given URI with the last prefix.
Add the necessary where clauses to the route based on its initial registration.
Merge the group stack with the controller action.
Determine if the action is routing to a controller.
Add a controller based route action to the action array.

comment.value: Here we'll merge any group "uses" statement if necessary so that the action
has the proper clause for this property. Then we can simply set the name
of the controller on the action and return the action array for usage.
Here we will set this controller name on the action array just so we always
have a copy of it for reference if we need it. This can be used while we
search for a controller name or do some other type of fetch operation.

description.compact: Prepend the last group uses onto the use clause.
Dispatch the request to the application.

comment.value: If no response was returned from the before filter, we will call the proper
route instance to get the response. If no route is found a response will
still get returned based on why no routes were found for this request.
Once this route has run and the response has been prepared, we will run the
after filter to do any last work on the response or for this application
before we will return the response back to the consuming code for use.

description.compact: Dispatch the request to a route and return the response.

comment.value: First we will find a route that matches this request. We will also set the
route resolver on the request so middlewares assigned to the route will
receive access to this route instance for checking of the parameters.
Once we have successfully matched the incoming request to a given route we
can call the before filters on that route. This works similar to global
filters in that if a response is returned we will not call the route.
After we have a prepared response from the route or filter we will call to
the "after" filters to do any last minute processing on this request or
response object before the response is returned back to the consumer.

description.compact: Run the given route within a Stack "onion" instance.

Resolve the middleware name to a class name preserving passed parameters.

Filter pattern filters that don't apply to the request verb.
Determine if the given pattern filters applies to a given method.
Call the given route's before (non-pattern) filters.

Clean the parameters being passed to a filter callback.
